title: Demolition of cranes atop collapsed Hard Rock Hotel delayed after more damage found
text:
CLOSE Terrifying video shows the moment the Hard Rock Hotel collapsed in downtown New Orleans, crashing onto Canal Street. Storyful

NEW ORLEANS — A week after the Hard Rock Hotel construction site partially collapsed along the edge of the French Quarter, the city has still not been able to demolish two massive, unstable cranes that appear to be shifting.

After announcing Friday a scheduled demolition could not take place and the cranes would be imploded Saturday, engineers attaching explosives discovered more damage, delaying their work again. Now the earliest the towering cranes could come down would be midday Sunday.

"The cranes are more damaged than thought, so they need to do things that are a little bit safer," said New Orleans Fire Chief Tim McConnell.

Several huge, concrete levels of the 18-story Hard Rock Hotel construction site on Canal Street, which divides the French Quarter and the Central Business District, partially collapsed Oct. 12, killing three workers and injuring dozens. The cause is under investigation by the federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration and the New Orleans Police Department.

Hard Rock Hotel collapse: Work starts to bring down cranes before coming storm

'Logically, it doesn't make sense': Engineer weighs in on Hard Rock Hotel collapse

Workers are raised in a crane bucket to prepare two unstable cranes for implosion at the collapse site of the Hard Rock Hotel, which underwent a partial, major collapse while under construction last Sat., Oct., 12, in New Orleans, Saturday, Oct. 19, 2019. (AP Photo/Gerald Herbert) (Photo: Gerald Herbert, AP)

The engineers brought in to attach explosives to the cranes have experience working on buildings damaged by both the 9/11 terrorist attack in New York and the 1995 bombing in Oklahoma City.

If all goes as planned during the implosion, the cross beams of the cranes will fold down like an umbrella and then the towers will drop in place.

Authorities are planning a larger evacuation around the site, including commercial and residential buildings, before they attempt to bring the cranes down.

The unstable cranes have moved back and forth a few inches throughout the week. Their shifting concerned authorities earlier this week as a tropical system threatened to bring gusty winds. After a rush to attempt to remove the cranes before the storm's expected gusts failed Friday, the plan was to take them down Saturday.

Tropical Storm Nestor tracked further east than expected, making landfall in the northeast Florida Panhandle Saturday and sparing New Orleans and the vulnerable Hard Rock site any impact.

'Very dangerous situation': Two dead, one still missing after Hard Rock hotel collapse

More: Tropical weather threat brings worry of further collapse to site of New Orleans hotel disaster

On Saturday under bright blue skies and milder temperatures, McConnell said one of the cranes shifted again but this time did not move back.

"That's tells me it's weakening," he said.

The engineers will continue to work through the night. Several hours before the implosion, the city will enforce a temporary evacuation zone around the Hard Rock site.

"As we said from the beginning, this has been a fluid operation," said Mayor LaToya Cantrell.

description: A week after the Hard Rock Hotel construction site partially collapsed, the city still hasn't been able to demolish the two shifting cranes on top.
